Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Phosphorus mobilization by legume cover crops in agricultural systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Agricultural productivity is often limited by the availability of soil nutrients, including phosphorus (P). Phosphorus availability in soils is limited because most soil P is not directly available to plants and natural inputs are insufficient to replace P removed by harvest. Applications of fertilizers or manures are thus required to maintain soil fertility and yields, but economically viable P reserves are declining and P losses from agricultural systems degrade aquatic ecosystems. This project evaluates whether cover crops, especially legumes, could provide P fertility for cash crops while reducing P input requirements by mobilizing soil P (converting P bound to soil minerals and organic matter into plant-available forms). The central objective is to identify how different species of cover crops could mobilize P. To do so, complementary approaches ? field measurements in long-term experiments, greenhouse studies, and computation of P budgets ? will be used. Measures will be taken of different forms of soil P, processes that mobilize P, transfer rates of P from cover crop to cash crop, and the overall importance of P mobilization by cover crops relative to other P fluxes at the farm scale.

This project will contribute to the development of alternative fertilization strategies that could maintain soil fertility while reducing costly P inputs. It will test whether using cover crops could contribute to this goal and provide a better understanding of P transformations in soils where different plant species grow. Because results from this project should be directly relevant to farm practitioners, this research will be coupled with outreach activities to disseminate results widely, including making the data publicly available, contributing to cover crop databases, and transferring knowledge through activities held outside of academic circles (field days, non-technical publications). This project will also involve undergraduate students and provide them with basic training in ecosystem science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

The primary goal of this research was to determine the effects of cover crops - crops that are incorporated in soils rather than harvested - on soil phosphorus (P) dynamics in intensive agricultural systems of California. Phosphorus is a major limiting nutrient in agriculture because most soil P is not directly available to plants and natural P inputs are small compared to P export in harvest. Therefore, external P inputs - fertilizers, manures - are required to maintain soil fertility. However, a high fraction of P applied in agricultural systems is not readily available to plants, resulting in P over-fertilization. Therefore, alternative approaches to maintain soil fertility while reducing P inputs are needed.

This research consisted of two greenhouse experiments complementing an existing PhD dissertation. The first experiment focused on the potential of different cover crops (legumes, cereals, mustard) to change soil properties - for example, pH - to "mobilize" soil P, i.e. increase the availability of soil P to plants. The second experiment quantified the transfer of P from cover crop residues to soils and a subsequent crop using radioactive isotopes.

Legumes had the greatest potential for P mobilization, but they did not actually increase soil P availability relative to other crops. Cover crop mixtures increased soil P availability slightly compared to monocultures. Overall, cover crops had a relatively minor effect on soil P availability via changes in soil properties, suggesting limited benefits for intensive agriculture.

In contrast, P transfer from cover crop residues to a subsequent wheat crop was high and comparable to P transfer measured with mineral fertilizer. There were few differences among cover crops, despite a three-fold variation in residue P concentration among species. Phosphorus transfer from residues was higher when soil P was lower, although all soils studied had a relatively high P concentration.

Overall, this research highlighted the limited capacity of cover crops to mobilize soil P in intensive agricultural systems. However, the magnitude of P transfer from cover crop residues to a subsequent wheat crop was comparable to what was measured with mineral P fertilizer, suggesting that cover crops can help manage soil P more efficiently in intensive agricultural systems.

 

Broader impacts

This project trained six undergraduate students from Stanford and one high-school student in conducting scientific research (experiment design, lab analyses, data analysis). Co-PI Maltais-Landry presented these results at two scientific meetings and he participated in two outreach activities - field days attended by over 100 participants (farmers, crop advisors, etc.) at Russell Ranch in Davis (California). Co-PI Maltais-Landry was trained in using cutting-edge techniques (liquid chromatography, isotope tracing) to conduct research that addresses basic research questions with potential applications in agriculture. Co-PI Maltais-Landry also developed his mentoring skills during the project. Overall, this research provides farmers working in intensive systems with tools to use cover crops to improve P management on their farms.
